lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “ear” and “air” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say: “bear, chair, ear, near.” Students repeat. Then sort words into “air” and “ear” columns on the board. Use choral practice.
stretchStrategies: After reading about pet therapists, students work in small groups to design a “New Job to Help People” (e.g., robot helper, happiness coach). They write 2–3 sentences describing what the job does and why it is useful, then present it briefly to the class.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
